content: The Transition toward Excellence, Achievement, and Mobility through Empowerment Act of 2011, also known as the TEAM-Empowerment Act of 2011, includes provisions for individualized transition plans and transition planning services administrative units. The Act also outlines findings and purposes. The Transition toward Excellence, Achievement, and Mobility through Empowerment Act of 2011, also known as the TEAM-Empowerment Act of 2011, includes findings that highlight the benefits of inclusive education, work experience, self-determination, flexible funding, and additional training for agency officials to improve outcomes for individuals with significant disabilities during their transition into adulthood. The Transition toward Excellence, Achievement, and Mobility through Empowerment Act of 2011 emphasizes the importance of seamless, collaborative strategies for individuals with significant disabilities during their transition into adulthood. Agency officials providing supports and services must receive additional training to address individual transition needs effectively. The Act aims to create a holistic system for successful transition, focus on high expectations, promote self-determination, and foster academic, professional, and social inclusion. The Transition toward Excellence, Achievement, and Mobility through Empowerment Act of 2011 emphasizes promoting innovative strategies for academic, professional, and social inclusion to ensure full integration into the community for individuals with significant disabilities. It also aims to better define and coordinate specific services for effective transition and eliminate barriers to collaboration for improving transition opportunities. Subtitle F--Adult Transition System is added to Title I of the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act of 2000, introducing individualized transition plans and transition planning services administrative units. The term 'asset development' refers to a strategy to help low-income workers and job seekers, including individuals with disabilities, achieve economic security through various means such as effective money management, education, home ownership, and retirement planning. 'Individualized education program' and 'integrated employment' are also defined in the context. The term 'ITP' refers to an individual transition plan developed under section 173, while 'local educational agency' and 'secondary school' have meanings defined in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. 'State intellectual and developmental disabilities agency' is responsible for services and supports for individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities. The Education Act of 1965 defines terms like 'State intellectual and developmental disabilities agency' as the primary agency responsible for services to individuals with disabilities, and 'transition services' as activities promoting movement from school to post-school activities. The Education Act of 1965 defines transition services as activities facilitating the move from school to post-school activities, such as vocational training, integrated employment, adult services, and independent living. These activities are tailored to individual student needs and preferences, encompassing instruction, community experiences, career preparation, work-based learning, youth development, self-advocacy training, family involvement, and peer mentoring. Transition services for students with disabilities include a range of activities like vocational training, youth development, self-advocacy training, and family involvement. These services aim to help students achieve outcomes like post-secondary education, integrated employment, independent living, and community participation. Facility-based employment settings are not included in these services. The Secretary provides state assistance through grants to carry out required activities under this subtitle. Payments are allocated based on a formula considering the number of individuals to be served in each state. Individualized transition plans are also addressed. Each State receiving assistance under this subtitle must develop an individual transition plan for individuals with developmental disabilities transitioning from the secondary school system. The plan aims to coordinate services for integrated employment, postsecondary education, independent living, and community engagement. The plan must be formulated within 30 days of graduation, applicable until age 26, and reviewed annually. The individual transition plan for individuals with developmental disabilities must be developed within 30 days of graduation, applicable until age 26, and reviewed annually. Meetings to develop the plan must include the individual, family, transition broker, vocational rehabilitation agency representative, and relevant service providers. An Individual Transition Plan (ITP) for individuals with developmental disabilities involves key stakeholders such as the vocational rehabilitation agency, service providers, transition coordinator, assistive technology experts, and workforce development representatives. The ITP must address postsecondary education, career preparation, work-based learning, leadership development, connecting activities, and family involvement. It should identify individual needs in these areas and outline how the State and its agencies will meet those needs. The Individual Transition Plan (ITP) for individuals with developmental disabilities includes addressing postsecondary education, career preparation, work-based learning, leadership development, connecting activities, and family involvement. It aims to identify individual needs in these areas and outline how the State and its agencies will meet those needs to advance economic self-sufficiency through asset development goals and specific tools. The Individual Transition Plan (ITP) for individuals with developmental disabilities includes addressing postsecondary education, career preparation, work-based learning, leadership development, connecting activities, and family involvement. SEC. 174 outlines the establishment of a Transition Planning and Services Administrative Unit. Each State receiving assistance under this subtitle must establish a Transition Planning and Services (TPS) administrative unit within the State intellectual and developmental disabilities agency. The primary focus of the TPS unit is to help individuals with developmental disabilities transition from the secondary school system to adulthood by developing and implementing Individual Transition Plans (ITPs) and employing transition brokers to coordinate with State agencies. Transition brokers are employed by the TPS administrative unit to facilitate coordination among State agencies in developing ITPs and provide assistance to individuals with developmental disabilities in navigating support services. Eligibility to serve as a transition broker requires expertise in developmental disabilities, benefits planning, transition services, employment, and job development. The individual must have expertise in developmental disabilities, benefits planning, transition services, employment, job development, workforce development, vocational rehabilitation, asset development, economic self-sufficiency tools, self-direction, and person-centered planning processes. The Transition Planning Services (TPS) administrative unit provides individuals with developmental disabilities and their families with knowledge on tax benefits, work incentives, matched savings plans, education financing, budget management, self-direction, person-centered planning, self-advocacy, self-determination skills, and peer mentoring. A transition broker is assigned to individuals based on their selection and approval by the State intellectual and developmental disabilities agency. The TPS administrative unit offers strategies for self-advocacy, self-determination skills, and peer mentoring to individuals with developmental disabilities and their families. They also provide information on Federal and State services, supports, and regulations, including asset development and financial savings tools. This information is updated quarterly for easy understanding. The State intellectual and developmental disabilities agency facilitates collaboration among key State agencies to improve services for individuals with developmental disabilities during the transition into adulthood. The Secretary is required to submit an annual report to Congress evaluating the implementation and effectiveness of the subtitle, including the number of individuals with Individual Transition Plans (ITPs) in each State, progress in ITP objectives, and demographic information of individuals with ITPs. $50,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2012 through 2016 to carry out this subtitle.
